channel.title: $500 Computer Project
channel.description: Well my computer is just not doing it anymore. Built in 2002, this baby is just not packing the heat I need it too! The graphics card is by some no name brand and the more graphic intense program it can run is Age of Empires III :(. I am looking to build a computer for $500 or under. I want it to be able to overclock it 3.0ghz at least! I want to go with the amd route because it is so much cheaper than intel and I can just overclock. Any suggestions on motherboards, CPUs, Cooling (fans,water,heatsinks, etc.). Cooling is the part I want to invest alot into since I am going to overclock it alot. The reason I am asking you guys for help is well I am a computer junkie and a programmer but when it comes to building computers I mean I know how the parts work and all of the parts I need but I end up getting un-compatible motherboards and it all falls apart from there.

item.title: $500 Computer Project
item.dc:creator: @nathanator22 nathanator22
item.description:
@nathanator22 wrote:

You could use this build i made for a friend of mine…It comes in at just under $500. Don’t know how well you could over clock the CPU though, and you defiantly want to turn on smart fan in the system bios or you would have heating issues.

Here are those web links in case you want them…(they are in order)

item.title: $500 Computer Project
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

sheepy:

I want to go with the amd route because it is so much cheaper than intel and I can just overclock.

AMD cpus generally are hotter than Intel ones thus making it not as easy to overclock.

xEnt:

CPU 2.8ghz C2D : 115$ (will oc to 3ghz - 3.2 with stock cooler) http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16819115206

I am really suprised in the decrease in price in c2d. I thought only the bottom range 1.8Ghz was $115

Read full topic

item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

Maybe i was just lucky then.

item.title: $500 Computer Project
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

with my Athlon 4000+ i managed to get 500mhz out of it, except a huge amount of people say AMD’s suck with overclocking, ill agree with them because it’s almost everywhere (except for phenom II’s).

Read full topic

item.title: $500 Computer Project
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

Uhh, i overclocked with this mobo easily. Amd Athlon X2 4800+, 2,4ghz stock speed. I got it up to 3,2ghz stable with stock cooler.

Read full topic

item.title: $500 Computer Project
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

Firstly if your overclocking don’t go with AMD, since they all suck at overclocking and you will struggle to pull an extra few hundred mhz, the Phenom II’s overclock well except almost all of they are stock 3ghz, and somewhat expensive for your build. Forget cooling because 500$ can’t get you fries with that.

Nice mobo Speljohan

CPU 2.8ghz C2D : 115$ (will oc to 3ghz - 3.2 with stock cooler) http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16819115206

4gb gskill ram. 40$ http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820231122

decent mobo: 87$ http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16813131329

320gb hdd: 50$ http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16822136098

9800GT oced: 115$ http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16814127406

IF you need a case

Nice looking case with 500w power supply (90$) http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16811156062

Total: 496.94$

this will pretty much anything out at the moment maxed out (except crysis maxed)

Read full topic

item.title: $500 Computer Project
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

Go with this motherboard: http://www.biostar.com.tw/app/en-us/t-series/introduction.php?S_ID=374

That’s what i use in my setup. Fucking awesome overclocking-possibilities for a very low price, + you can always buy a second pci-express card and run crossfire (like i do). There’s also a built-in gfx card that isn’t too shabby. It’s better than the average built-in card and supports gaming to an extent.

Read full topic
